channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Embattled Nuclear Plant Is Rejoined to Grid, as U.N. Inspectors Seek Access
item.description: Shelling and nearby fires have added urgency to fears over the plant’s safe operation, as some power returns to southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian heavy artillery crew near Chasiv Yar, in the Donbas region of Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Pokes the Russian Bear With Attacks and Mockery
item.description: Driven by deep anger at Russia and the need to rally support at home and abroad, Ukraine is regularly goading its much more powerful antagonist.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians wrapped themselves in the country’s flags at Maidan Square during the parade of captured Russian tanks as they celebrated Independence Day in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: U.K. Energy Price Cap to Rise 80%, Regulator Says
item.description: A regulator detailed the latest increase in gas and electric charges, driven up by the war in Ukraine and expected to further stoke inflation.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stanley Reed
item.category: Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem) (Great Britain)
item.media:description: An apartment complex in London. British households are being hit with big price increases for electricity and natural gas.

item.title: China’s Record Drought is Drying Rivers and Feeding Its Coal Habit
item.description: Dry weather in southwestern China has crippled huge hydroelectric dams, forcing cities to impose rolling blackouts and driving up the country’s use of coal.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The dry riverbed of the Jialing River, a tributary of the Yangtze, last week in Chongqing in southwestern China.

item.title: ‌A Social Media Star of a Changed Middle East: An Arab From Israel in Dubai
item.description: Nuseir Yassin, a Palestinian citizen of Israel with nearly 60 million followers, has taken advantage of new diplomatic ties to move to the United Arab Emirates — angering many Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuseir Yassin, a Palestinian born and raised in Israel, was one of the first Israeli passport holders to take advantage of new diplomatic relations between Israel and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Ethiopian Airstrike Hits Kindergarten as Fighting Spreads in Tigray
item.description: Local medics said seven people died, including several children, as the region in northern Ethiopia plunged deeper into conflict just days after a truce collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video, showing destruction at a playground in Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, on Friday.

item.title: Putin Orders an Expansion of Russia’s Hard-Hit Armed Forces
item.description: The decree suggests that President Vladimir V. Putin expects a prolonged war in Ukraine, but he stopped short of full mobilization, and it was not clear how the military would reach his goal.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian soldiers at a captured Ukrainian position near Schastia, a town in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine, in June.

item.title: Fighting Between U.S. and Iran-Backed Militias Escalates in Syria
item.description: Two strikes on U.S. military sites have been tied to forces aligned with Iran, raising tensions just as Washington appears close to striking a new nuclear deal with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Raja Abdulrahim and Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American forces patrolling in Syria’s northeastern Hasakeh Province in May.

item.title: Inflation Hits the British Breakfast Table With Rising Food Prices
item.description: From bread to butter to baked beans, a survey of typical breakfast items makes clear that there’s no relief from rising inflation for Britons when they sit down for their morning meal.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Consumer prices in Britain rose 10.1 percent in July from the previous year.

item.title: Spain Passes Law Requiring ‘Freely Expressed’ Consent for Sex
item.description: The law comes six years after the gang rape of an 18-year-old woman stirred mass protests and a general reckoning over the rights of sexual abuse victims.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and José Bautista
item.media:description: A demonstration in front of Spain’s Parliament in 2018 against the release on bail of five men who had raped a teenager.

item.title: ​Decades After a ‘Living Hell,’ Korean Victims​ Win a Step Toward Redress
item.description: Brothers Home was supposed to help get people off the streets, but a government commission has confirmed its role in detentions and other abuses was a “grave human rights violation by the state.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Park Sun-yi, a victim of Brothers Home, at a news conference on Wednesday at the Truth and Reconciliation Commission office in Seoul.

item.title: Liz Truss Makes a Strong Bid for Downing Street
item.description: Campaigning to be Britain’s next prime minister, Liz Truss has modeled herself after Margaret Thatcher and pushed a party orthodoxy of lower taxes, less government and bucking the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Liz Truss, a candidate to lead Britain’s Conservative Party and become prime minister, campaigning on Tuesday at a party gathering in Birmingham, England.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Former Leader, Appears in Court
item.description: The police were ordered not to arrest the former prime minister, who has been charged under Pakistan’s antiterrorism act, before a hearing set for next Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s former prime minister, in Lahore this month. In recent months, he has drawn tens of thousands to his rallies.

item.title: Ukraine Weighs a Risky Offensive to Break Out of a Stalemate
item.description: Both Russia and Ukraine are preparing for a protracted standoff, but Ukraine has greater incentive to try to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian heavy artillery crew after going for a swim in a lake near Chasiv Yar, in the Donbas region in Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: This Is Not the Monkeypox That Doctors Thought They Knew
item.description: The patients turning up at clinics often have a range of symptoms that are not typical of the infection. Some of the infected seem to have no symptoms at all.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: KC Nwakalor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Dimie Ogoina, author of a study of monkeypox cases in Nigeria that documented unusual new symptoms. “If what is happening in Europe and the global North had not happened, I don’t think that paper would be discussed,” he said.

item.title: Here Are the Challenges Ahead for California’s Ban on Gas Cars
item.description: Enforcement could be complex and legal challenges are likely. But ultimately, experts say, success or failure will depend on steady supply and buyers’ appetite.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California’s policy will reverberate across the nation.

item.title: Latvia tears down a controversial Soviet-era monument in its capital.
item.description: A 260-foot-tall obelisk erected in 1985 to honor Soviet soldiers who ended the country’s World War II Nazi occupation was toppled on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: E.P.A. to Designate PFAS, or ‘Forever Chemicals,’ as Hazardous
item.description: A proposed rule would require companies to report spills of two toxic chemicals that have been linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: PFAS chemicals have been found in a range of products including carpets, waterproof clothing and food packaging, including some microwave popcorn bags.

item.title: Zelensky Is Under Pressure to Launch a Counteroffensive
item.description: Both sides are preparing for a protracted war, but Ukraine has an incentive to counterattack this fall, before the rainy season.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers on both sides of the war have spent the last few weeks dug in trenches, weathering artillery bombardments and without any signs of meaningful advance.

item.title: Conspiracy Theories
item.description: How more funding for the I.R.S. became a political firestorm.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: The Dugong ‘Sea Cow’ Has Vanished from China’s Waters, Study Says
item.description: The study said the dugong, a vegetarian mammal that ranges across Asia and Africa, has essentially vanished from the country’s coastline.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A dugong in the lagoons of New Caledonia, east of Australia. The species has become the first large vertebrate to go “functionally extinct” in China’s coastal waters.

item.title: How to Plan a Sustainable Trip
item.description: Organizing a responsible visit to sensitive areas like the Galápagos Islands or Antarctica involves research, decoding certifications and possibly a travel adviser.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Review: “The Arc of a Covenant,” by Walter Russell Mead
item.description: In “The Arc of a Covenant,” Walter Russell Mead makes the case that U.S. support for the Jewish state has benefited America more than critics allow.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tepperman
item.media:description: Activists in Jerusalem, October 2020.

item.title: The Long Tail of Covid-19 Disinformation
item.description: Almost all of Australia and New Zealand’s pandemic restrictions have been lifted. Yet the protests continue.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A protest last November in Sydney, Australia, against vaccine mandates and Covid lockdowns.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Vladimir Putin will expand Russia’s military.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A Russian Army recruiting billboard that reads: “Serving Russia is a real job!”

item.title: Cluster Munitions Have Killed Nearly 700 Civilians in Ukraine, Study Says.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spent remains of Russian cluster munitions found on farm fields near Siversk, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, in June.

item.title: The U.S. State Department and Yale identify 21 detention sites in Russian-controlled territory.
item.description: The sites are sometimes used to deport prisoners. And researchers found evidence of disturbed earth on two recent occasions consistent with mass graves.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: A satellite image showed a general view of a prison in Olenivka, Ukraine, in July. Researchers said they found evidence of disturbed earth there consistent with mass graves.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.N. Delays Report on Abuse in Xinjiang
item.description: Plus an expansion of Russia’s armed forces and France’s proposal to ban private jets
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A detention facility in Dabancheng, Xinjiang, last year. Former detainees have described physical abuse, mistreatment and hours of indoctrination in official Communist Party ideology.

item.title: Biden and Zelensky reaffirm their alliance as the war enters its seventh month.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden in the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Austin Orders Overhaul to Better Protect Civilians During U.S. Combat Operations
item.description: A Pentagon plan envisions broad changes to military doctrine, planning and training aimed at mitigating the risk of harm to noncombatants.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Azmat Khan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said the Pentagon must prioritize civilian protection and incorporate more attentive thinking about that goal as doctrine in its mission planning.

item.title: Scuba Diver Is Fined After Getting Too Close to Killer Whales
item.description: Canadian investigators said the diver “attempted to motor ahead of the whale pod several times” in British Columbia in 2020. He was fined 12,000 Canadian dollars.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: Putin Orders an Increase in the Size of the Russian Military
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A full six months after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ordered the invasion of Ukraine, he signed a decree increasing the number of service members in the country’s armed forces.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Cut Off From Power Grid, Officials Say
item.description: The director of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog said that the episode underscored the danger at the plant, where shelling has damaged power lines and other infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, which provides one-fifth of the power needs in Ukraine, was disconnected from the nation’s grid on Thursday, causing large-scale power outages in southern Ukraine.

item.title: U.N. Report on Xinjiang Human Rights May Be Delayed Again
item.description: The high commissioner for human rights has repeatedly postponed its release, reinforcing perceptions that U.N. leadership is reluctant to stand up to China.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A detention facility in Dabancheng, Xinjiang, last year. Former detainees have described physical abuse, mistreatment and hours of indoctrination in official Communist Party ideology.

item.title: Spiders Are Caught in a Global Web of Misinformation
item.description: Researchers looked at thousands of spider news stories to study how sensationalized information spreads. Their findings could be broadly applicable.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Myanmar Arrests Vicky Bowman, Former British Ambassador
item.description: Vicky Bowman is among several foreigners who have been arrested in the Southeast Asian nation after the military seized power in a coup last year.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Jonathan Wong/South China Morning Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vicky Bowman and her husband, Ko Htein Lin, in 2008.

item.title: Biden’s Debt Relief
item.description: The president’s plan focuses on less affluent student borrowers.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Student loan borrowers rallied outside of the Education Department building in Washington in April to pressure President Biden to wipe out their debt with an executive order.

item.title: As France Swelters, Private Jets Come Under Attack
item.description: Politicians are proposing regulating or banning flights by such planes after a summer of extreme heat and soaring energy prices prompted growing calls to tackle the causes of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut

item.title: Defiant Under Russian Strikes, Ukrainians Celebrate a Nation ‘Reborn’
item.description: At least 22 people were killed in a missile strike on a rail station in eastern Ukraine, officials said. Celebrating the country’s Independence Day, Ukrainian leaders urged resolve.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of a soldier who was killed on the front line visited his grave in Lviv, in western Ukraine, on Wednesday, the country’s Independence Day.

item.title: Facebook, Twitter and Others Remove Pro-U.S. Influence Campaign
item.description: It was the first time that an influence operation promoting U.S. interests abroad had been discovered and taken down from the social media platforms.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Meta and Twitter said they were removing accounts associated with an influence campaign that promoted U.S. foreign policy interests abroad.

item.title: U.N. officials paint a bleak picture as civilian casualties top 13,000.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed the U.N. Security Council on Wednesday at the U.N.’s headquarters in New York.

item.title: C.I.A. Begins Compensating Victims of Havana Syndrome
item.description: Officers and diplomats have reported ailments arising from mysterious incidents since 2016. But lawyers for some say future cases may be harder to adjudicate.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The American Embassy in Havana. U.S. personnel injured in mysterious health incidents in Havana and other places can receive up to $187,300 in compensation.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Six Months of War in Ukraine
item.description: Plus the future of milk in India and South Korea’s declining fertility rate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen walking through a school bombed by Russian forces in Mykolaiv region this month.

item.title: On the eastern front, a Ukrainian unit sees little change on Independence Day.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Berlin, a commander of a Ukrainian army unit on the eastern front lines, has seen his unit of about 120 men reduced to 55 after Russian attacks.

item.title: The Mood of Ukraine’s Independence Day? Defiance.
item.description: Volunteers raised a Ukrainian flag over a giant Soviet-era monument in Kyiv as President Volodymyr Zelensky gave a speech in front of ruined Russian tanks in the city’s center.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: The attack was one of the deadliest strikes on the country’s railways since April.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Why Andrew Tate’s Social Media Accounts Are Being Removed
item.description: TikTok, YouTube and Facebook have taken down accounts belonging to Mr. Tate, a 35-year-old British American.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Fearing energy shortages, Germany prioritizes fuel shipments on railways.
item.description: Berlin issued a slew of national mandates to save energy and secure supplies to power plants as a feared winter energy shortage is worsened by Europe’s summer drought.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo ship is loaded with coal in Rheinberg, Germany, in August. The Rhine’s water level is so low that ships can be loaded with only one-third of the usual amount of coal.

item.title: Fighting Near Tigray Region of Ethiopia Shatters Cease-Fire
item.description: Clashes on the border of the Tigray region raised concern about another wave of violence in a ruinous civil war and fueled fears about the fate of millions already on the verge of famine.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebel fighters outside Mekelle, the capital of the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray, last year.

item.title: California to Ban the Sale of New Gasoline Cars
item.description: The decision, to take effect by 2035, will very likely speed a wider transition to electric vehicles because many other states follow California’s standards.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. At least 12 other states are already in line to adopt California’s zero-emissions vehicle mandate.

item.title: Biden Announces Nearly $3 Billion Package of Military Aid for Ukraine
item.description: The aid, part of a $40 billion assistance package approved by Congress in May, is a sign of the administration’s determination to assist in the fight against Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and John Ismay

item.title: South Korea’s Fertility Rate Is World’s Lowest, Again
item.description: The data reflects societal problems both present and future, including young adults’ economic anxiety and a looming shortage of workers to pay into the pension system.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Children playing in Seoul last year. The costs of housing, child care and education costs have led many in South Korea to not have children.

item.title: Churchill Portrait Disappears in Art Heist in Canada
item.description: An original print of the famous photograph taken by Yousuf Karsh is missing after staff at a hotel in Ottawa realized last week that someone had swapped it for a fake.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: Yousuf Karsh’s famous portrait of Winston Churchill, taken in December 1941 in Ottawa.

item.title: Tim Page, Gonzo Photographer of the Vietnam War, Is Dead at 78
item.description: Fearless and free-spirited, he pushed the boundaries of life and photography, recording intimate images of combat that helped shift the course of the war.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans

item.title: Yevgeny Roizman, Ukraine War Critic, Is Detained in Russia
item.description: Yevgeny Roizman, the former mayor of the city of Yekaterinburg, is accused of “discrediting” the Russian Army.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The former mayor of Yekaterinburg, Yevgeny Roizman, was detained on Wednesday on charges of “discrediting” the Russian military.

item.title: Deniers, Enablers, Accepters
item.description: We break down elected Republicans into three groups, based on their stances toward false claims about the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Rachel Mummey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trump supporters at a rally in Menon, Ill. in June.

item.title: Can an Iconic Italian Wool Survive a Changing Economy?
item.description: Casentino cloth has been finished for centuries by workers in a remote Tuscan valley. Today they are threatened by eviction.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition at the Museo dell’Arte della Lana, which showcases the art of wool making, in Stia, Italy, in August.

item.title: India, a Dairy Titan, Studies How to Keep Milk Flowing in a Hotter World
item.description: As rising prices draw headlines, Indian scientists are getting creative in an effort to help producers, and animals, adapt.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cows at the National Dairy Research Institute in Karnal, India, where scientists study the impact of climate change on milk production.
